title: What is CAMHS?
body:
CAMHS is an NHS run service that provides specialist support to young people who are experiencing emotional, behavioural or mental health difficulties.

The service is made up of highly trained people with lots of different skills. They will work with you to understand your situation and together you’ll decide on the best type of treatment to suit your needs.

The name CAMHS stands for Child and Adolescent Mental Health Service. The North Staffordshire CAMHS service supports young people from pre-school age up to 18 years old.

title: How can CAMHS help?
body:
CAMHS staff see lots of people who are having difficulties with their emotions, behaviour or mental health.

CAMHS can help with lots of different types of issues, including fears and phobias, feeling anxious, low mood, behaviour, self-harm and eating issues among many others.

CAMHS staff won’t judge you for finding things difficult. They also understand that it can be scary and difficult to talk about yourself in an unfamiliar place.

title: Who should I talk to?
body:
Start by speaking to one of the following people about the difficulties you are experiencing:

  • school nurse, counsellor or liaison worker
  • teacher
  • doctor
  • health worker
  • social worker

You can do this together with the help of your parents, carer or a friend if you would find that easier. Speaking to one of these people is an important first step towards finding help. They can provide support and advice about your worries.

title: Preparing to talk to someone
body:
It’s not unusual to feel nervous, vulnerable or scared about talking to someone else about what’s happening in your life.

Creating a checklist can help you prepare what you want to say when you talk to someone for the first time. Another useful tool called Doc Ready can help you to prepare for a GP appointment.

If the person you speak to feels that you’d benefit from the the help of someone with specialist experience of helping young people with their mental health, then they may make what’s called a referral, which is where they contact CAMHS to ask them to make an appointment with you.

title: How long does it take to see CAMHS?
body:
CAMHS always tries to see people as quickly as possible once they have been given their details. However, because lots of people are finding they need help or support it can sometimes take up to six months for an appointment.

Please don’t let the potential waiting time stop you from speaking to someone about your what’s going on in your life.

There are plenty of other sources of help which can also support you. See the ‘Where can I go for more support?’ section below for more information.

title: Where can I go for more support?
body:
There are lots of places you can go for help and support. The resources listed below are a mixture of websites, phone lines and face to face support.

It can also be helpful to speak to your teacher, doctor, parents or carers to find out how they could help whilst you wait for your appointment. You can create a checklist to help you prepare to speak to any of these people.

  • Young Minds - Website full of useful info and advice about mental health
  • Childline - Call 0800 1111 (free and confidential)
  • ReThink
  • Mind
  • Changes Health and WellBeing - A user-led mental health charity in Staffordshire

title: How will I find out if I'm able to see CAMHS?
body: Once the CAMHS team have received your information the following things will happen:

title: Receive a letter from CAMHS
body:
You’ll receive a letter from the service within two weeks of them getting your information which will ask you to confirm that you want to see CAMHS.

If you are under 16 years old then a letter may also be sent to your parents or carer. If you would prefer that they didn’t receive a letter then mention this to the person who is giving your information to CAMHS (e.g. your GP, School Nurse etc.)

This letter will give you information about how to arrange your appointment. You will be asked to arrange an appointment within two weeks of receiving this letter to confirm that you still want to see CAMHS.

title: Make an appointment
body: Follow the instructions on your letter to arrange an appointment - you can do it online or over the phone. Don’t worry if you lose your letter for any reason; it this happens just call the CAMHS team on 0300 123 0984 and let them know that you don’t have your letter and they will help you.

title: Receive details of your appointment
body:
Once you’ve chosen your appointment you and your parents or carer will receive another letter from CAMHS giving you more information about your visit. As well as the time and date of your appointment, this letter will also tell you where to go for your visit and who you will see on the day.

Many different types of staff are expertly trained to deliver first appointments so the person you see could have one of several job titles. See the 'who works at CAMHS?' section below to learn more about the different roles and what they do.

title: Complete the Questionnaire
body:
The letter containing your appointment details will also include a questionnaire for you and your parents or carer to complete.

This questionnaire is used to help the person you will see at CAMHS better understand how you are currently feeling. It is not a test and there are no right or wrong answers so be as honest as you can.

It is good to fill this form out and bring it with you on your first visit as it will help the person you see at CAMHS get a quicker understanding of what matters to you. Creating a checklist to describe what’s currently happening in your life can help you to fill out the questionnaire.

title: What should I do before my first visit?
body:
Creating your own checklist is a great way to prepare for your first visit. Doing this can help you identify and organise your thoughts, feelings and behaviours to make them easier to talk about during your first visit. Creating a checklist can also help you think about what changes you’d like to achieve by visiting CAMHS.

It’s a good idea to bring your checklist to your first appointment so that you don’t forget anything you want to talk about. It’s easy to download, print or email your checklist.

title: CAMHSReady and your privacy
body:
CAMHSReady doesn't store anything that we or anyone else can link to you. Nothing stays on the server and nothing stays on your phone or computer.

We do use Google Analytics to help us measure how we're doing and improve the site, but that data isn't linked to you in any way.

You can choose to email your checklist to yourself, or to download it, or to print it, and what you do with it then is up to you. We don't even store items people add to their checklists, just the topics people look at.

If you have any other questions or concerns about your privacy when using CAMHSReady, please contact us

title: What happens at your first appointment?
Does my parent or carer come with me?
body:
If you are under 16 years old CAMHS will normally ask your parent or carer to come with you to the appointment. It can often help to have them there as some people can feel nervous about their visit and having a parent or carer can help provide reassurance and familiarity.

Depending on your situation, the the person you are seeing may also invite your parent or carer to join you in your appointment to help get a better understanding of your life. If you would prefer that they didn’t join your appointment then let the person you see at CAMHS know when you arrive.

title: Meeting your CAMHS Worker
body:
When you arrive at the building you will be greeted by one of the receptionists. They will let the person you are seeing know that you have arrived and will explain to you where to go.

You will then be met by the person who you were told that you would be seeing in your appointment letter. They will introduce themselves and show you to a room where you will be able to have your appointment in privacy. They will then explain to you how the appointment works.

title: How long does the appointment last?
body: A first appointment usually lasts an hour but can last up to 90 minutes if there is a lot of information to cover.

title: What questions will they ask me?
body:
The person you are seeing will ask you to describe what you are currently experiencing difficulties with and when these began. They will also ask you what you would ideally like to be different by visiting CAMHS.

They ask these questions to help get a better understanding of your situation and how best to help you. They’ll use what you say to work out what could be wrong or what might help, so it really helps to be open. Don't worry if you struggle to talk about your problems; they won’t judge you and they understand how difficult it can be to talk about yourself.

Creating a checklist can help you prepare what you’d like to talk about and remember it during the session. If you have brought your checklist with you to your visit then share it with the person you're seeing as it will really help them know what to begin talking to you about.

title: Will they take notes?
body: The person you are seeing will usually make some notes during your visit to help them remember later on what you discussed.

title: Can I ask questions?
body: It's your appointment so don’t be afraid to ask any questions, especially if the person you are seeing says something you don’t understand or which doesn’t sound right to you. A good way to make sure you’ve understood what they have said to you is repeating it back to them, asking if you’ve got it right.

title: What will happen at the end of the appointment?
body:
At the end of your appointment the person you are seeing will explain what they think the important factors for you are and what they think should happen next.

They will use their professional training and experience to understand the information you have shared with them and make recommendations that they think will help support you best. They may give you some leaflets and information to take with you to help you remember any of their advice.

It’s your appointment so ask them questions if you don’t understand anything they have said or would like to know more information.

title: Can I change or cancel my appointment?
body:
If for any reason you need to rearrange or cancel your appointment then please call the CAMHS Team on 0300 123 0984 to let them know and they will help you.

Letting the CAMHS Team know in advance that you won’t be able to attend your appointment can allow them to use your time slot to see another young person who needs their help.

If you are thinking about not attending your appointment because you are anxious or scared then please know that it is not unusual to feel this way. Try to think of your appointment as the next step to getting help with what you’re going through. If you don’t go, then the CAMHS team won’t be able to help you. Most people who attend CAMHS are pleasantly surprised to learn that their experience is much better than they originally expected.

title: What happens after my first appointment?
Receive a follow up letter
body:
You and your parents or carer will receive a letter from the CAMHS worker you saw which will sum up what they learned from your visit, explain their reccomendedations ande describe the next steps you can take.

The person you met with will also send a copy of this letter to your doctor, as well as the person who referred you to CAMHS, to keep them updated on your progress.

title: Next Steps
body:
The next steps for each person who visits CAMHS will be different as it depends on what you and the person you saw decided is the best type of support for you.

This can vary from deciding that you don't need any further support at the moment, through to seeing a specialist from CAMHS or another service for more appointments.

title: What happens if I’m recommended more CAMHS Appointments?
body:
You and your parents or carer will receive a letter with instructions on how to book your next appointment. Once you’ve made your booking, you’ll receive a letter confirming the details of your appointment, including who you’re going to see.

The person you are seeing may be different from the person you saw at your first appointment because the CAMHS team will match you with the person they think is best placed to help you based on the information they learned from your first visit. To learn more about the different roles at CAMHS see the ‘Who Works at CAMHS?’ section below.

At your next appointment your new CAMHS Worker will talk with you to decide together how often you will see each other. They will also explain how your therapy will work. Again, don’t be afraid to ask any questions as it’s your therapy and they won’t expect you to know what is going to happen.

title: Who works at CAMHS?
body:
On your first visit to CAMHS the person you see could have any one of the following roles, as a mixture of staff have been specially trained to take first visits. In your appointment letter you will be told which person you will be seeing.

Click on a profile below to learn more about each role and the methods they use to help people.

title: Cognitive Behavioural Therapist (CBT)
body: Cognitive behavioural therapists work together with people to help them learn new skills and feel more in control of their lives. CBT is especially useful in lots of circumstances, especially when people are dealing with depression, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive disorder and phobias.

title: Psychological Therapist
body: Psychological therapists help people recognise their emotions, as well as how those emotions affect thoughts and actions. This type of therapy is especially useful for helping people be kinder to themselves and find better ways of dealing with difficult situations.

title: Art Therapist
body: Art therapists use a variety of artistic activities, including painting, drawing and collages to explore how people feel in a non-threatening way. You don’t have to be good at art to benefit from this type of therapy; it’s very useful for helping anyone who finds it difficult to talk about they feel.

title: Drama Therapist
body: Drama therapists use acting and play to help people explore relationships and think about things from others’ perspectives. This type of therapy can be especially useful for families or people who struggle to talk about the things they’re feeling.

title: Psychological Parenting and Play Specialist (PPP)
body: CAMHS doesn’t just work with young people. PPP specialists play an important role: they can take the skills parents already have and develop them, helping them deal with the challenges of being a parent. This type of therapy can be especially useful for families with parents who are dealing with their own difficulties

title: Systemic Family Practitioner
body: Systemic family practitioners help families discover their strengths and find new ways to support one another. This type of therapy can be especially useful for families who are interested in working together to become closer, happier, and stronger.

title: Clinical Psychologist
body: Because of their extensive training, clinical psychologists are able to draw on a wide variety of skills. This makes them especially helpful in circumstances where one person might benefit from lots of different approaches.

title: Receptionist
body: Receptionists are responsible for keeping CAMHS running. They manage appointments, maintain clients’ details and even make the tea. Receptionists are especially good at creating an environment that’s friendly, organised and welcoming.

title: Where is North Staffordshire CAMHS?
body:
North Staffordshire CAMHS is based across four different sites in the region.

The CAMHS team try their hardest to see you at the location that suits you best. This could be the one nearest to your home or school. When you or your parents/carer book your appointment you will be told which location to go to.

Click on the name of a CAMHS site below to show its location on Google Maps. You can use this to get directions to the site, as well as using streetview to see images of the buildings.

Tunstall - CAMHS and First Steps Building , Roundwell Street, Tunstall, ST6 5JJ
